urls.title: The Chilterns AONB - News
urls.description: Buckinghamshire Council and the Chilterns Conservation Board have serious concerns about the impacts of HS2‚Äôs tunnelling operations on Buckinghamshire‚Äôs aquifer and chalk streams. These concerns relate to pollution resulting from tunnelling operations, increasing abstraction of water and impacts on the flow of significant chalk streams, such as the River Misbourne. A joint Position Statement has been issued with a series of questions regarding these concerns, and the Council and the Chilterns Conservation

@georgecmcgavin @JWillson1 @hayulls @Lucy_Lapwing @LGSpace @Buzz_dont_tweet @DandelionAppre1 @Love_plants @wildflower_hour @WildFlowerSoc @BiodiversitySoS @MeadowInGarden @DaveGoulson @RewildingB @banburyfm @banburynews @Cherwellcouncil @TownEvents @EnvAgency Many councils are banning use of pesticides in public areas @PAN_UK can help and may have a local group.

@Anna_Dillon @ChilternsAONB @BucksCouncil @EnvAgency @Feargal_Sharkey @AquiferChalk Yep. 
Recent chalk stream abstraction reductions = one step forward.

HS2 10+mL/day requirements = two steps backward. 
I hope our brown trout and other aquatic inhabitants are rapidly evolving lungs, 'cause there ain't gonna be too much water flowing.*

*Except üí©discharges...

Here is a good statement reflecting our concerns with regard to HS2 Tunnelling and the impact on the chalk aquifer https://t.co/tUIdNMbtSW
It is with sadness we announce a very compliant @EnvAgency have approved the tunnelling without any public consultation.

urls.title: The Chilterns AONB - News
urls.description: Buckinghamshire Council and the Chilterns Conservation Board have serious concerns about the impacts of HS2‚Äôs tunnelling operations on Buckinghamshire‚Äôs aquifer and chalk streams. These concerns relate to pollution resulting from tunnelling operations, increasing abstraction of water and impacts on the flow of significant chalk streams, such as the River Misbourne. A joint Position Statement has been issued with a series of questions regarding these concerns, and the Council and the Chilterns Conservation

tweets.text:
@Anna_Dillon @ChilternsAONB @BucksCouncil @EnvAgency @Feargal_Sharkey @AquiferChalk Therefore NONE of the models they are relying on as evidence of safe tunnelling are sound. garbage in, garbage out. First rule of modeling. There's insufficient data to be confident they won't disrupt the entire system. 
And don't get me started on all the other knock on effects!

@Anna_Dillon @ChilternsAONB @BucksCouncil @EnvAgency @Feargal_Sharkey @AquiferChalk It reminds me of the same stupidity that was circulating decades ago, when it was suggested that nuclear waste could be safely disposed of by firing it at the sun.  You shouldn't tamper with a natural system that isn't fully understood! We don't understand the aquifer fully.

@EnvAgencyMids After some soul searching I‚Äôm taking the decision to not renew my licence this year , it‚Äôs only a small gesture but I can‚Äôt justify giving you money . I‚Äôd rather no go fishing than do that ! @Cap_it_off @StinkStopthe

tweets.text: 1/2: As @EnvAgency turns 25, Guy Linley-Adams of @SalmonTroutCons asks "is the Environment Agency doing its job?" via @wcl_news https://t.co/IT3e9npkLT

urls.title: Is the Environment Agency doing its job?
urls.description: Guy Linley-Adams, Solicitor to Salmon & Trout Conservation, shares the findings from their new report on the role of the Environment Agency & why greater investment is needed to make our rivers, lakes, and streams healthy by 2027.
